communities.title: The News of the World Phone Hacking Scandal
communities.summary:
The community revolves around the News of the World, a British tabloid newspaper that was at the center of a major phone hacking scandal. The newspaper, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, was found to have systematically hacked the voicemail messages of various public figures, including celebrities, politicians, and even victims of crime and their families. This unethical and illegal practice allowed the newspaper to obtain private information and use it in their stories without the knowledge or consent of the individuals involved.

The phone hacking scandal was not an isolated incident, but rather a widespread practice within the News of the World. Several investigations, including Operation Weeting, Operation Nigeria, Operation Motorman, and Operation Glade, uncovered the extent of the phone hacking activities at the newspaper. Numerous high-profile individuals, including journalists, editors, and executives, were arrested and charged in connection with these illegal practices.

Rupert Murdoch, the media mogul and founder of News Corporation, owned the News of the World and faced significant public and political scrutiny over the scandal. The phone hacking scandal had far-reaching consequences for Murdoch's media empire, leading to the closure of the News of the World and numerous legal and regulatory challenges.

The Guardian newspaper played a crucial role in exposing the phone hacking scandal, with journalist Nick Davies publishing the initial article that brought the issue to light. The Guardian's continued reporting on the unfolding scandal helped to keep the public informed and hold those responsible accountable.

The phone hacking scandal at the News of the World had ripple effects across the media industry in the UK, with other publications, such as the Daily Mirror, also being investigated for similar practices. In response, the Daily Mirror announced that it would be conducting its own internal review of its editorial procedures and practices to address the issues that led to the phone hacking scandal.
